claim: Humanity is past the event horizon: the AI takeoff has started and we are close to building digital superintelligence—current systems already exceed people in many ways and are significantly amplifying human output, so the least-likely technical barriers have largely been overcome.

AI-driven acceleration of scientific progress and productivity will produce enormous gains to quality of life (e.g., faster discovery of cures, new materials, brain‑computer interfaces, and space capabilities), making the future potentially vastly better than the present if harnessed well.

Self-reinforcing feedback loops—AI tools accelerating AI research (a larval form of recursive self‑improvement), economic flywheels funding infrastructure, and robots/datacenters that can build more robots/datacenters—will cause rapid exponential acceleration in capabilities and drive the marginal cost of intelligence toward the cost of electricity.

Specific near‑term technical milestones are plausible: 2025 will see AI agents performing real cognitive work and transforming software development, 2026 will likely produce systems that can generate novel scientific insights, and 2027 may bring robots capable of real‑world tasks, with much larger societal changes unfolding through the 2030s.

While many everyday human activities (family, creativity, leisure) will remain recognizable, the 2030s are likely to be wildly different in important ways because intelligence and energy will become abundant, enabling capabilities previously limited by those two factors—assuming good governance.

Solving the alignment problem—robustly ensuring AI systems learn and act toward what we collectively really want over the long term—is a prerequisite, followed by making superintelligence cheap, widely available, and not overly concentrated in the hands of a single person, company, or country.

Three economic observations underpin rapid AI impact: model intelligence scales roughly with the log of resources (compute, data, inference), the cost to use a given level of AI has been falling ~10x per year (driving vastly more use), and linear increases in intelligence produce super‑exponential socioeconomic value, so continued heavy investment is likely.

Public policy, governance, and societal conversation matter greatly: we should balance safety with individual empowerment (including more openness), consider mechanisms to broadly distribute compute/AI access to avoid worsening capital‑labor imbalances, and prevent authoritarian concentration of AI for population control.
